messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hello Justin,


Am Dienstag, 25. März 2003 13:32 schrieb uweanimal:
> Hi,
>
> I am trying to write some test cases but I am not sure how to do it.
>
> I have a program which takes a XML input file and runs it through an
> XSLT process.
>
> What is the best way to test that this has been achieved sucessfully?
Logically or physically (implementation)?
Logically, you could do this by:
a) Validation against DTD or Schema
b) asserting some XPath expressions

String comparisons of course won't do:
"<img xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' src='...' alt='...'/>" and
'<html:img alt="..." src="..." xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
></htmlimg>' are unequal Strings but equal XML Elements.

String comparisons will only do if both the actual XML and expected XML String
are canonical XML, and even then success is very limited:
- - The indention and other whitespace considered ignorable might still differ
- - The contents of processing instructions and maybe even comments that are
semantically identical might differ, e.g. <?xml-stylesheet type="text/css"
href="bla.css"?> vs. <?xml-stylesheet href="bla.css" type="text/css"?>

So, don't use String comparisons. I'm sure you already figured that out.

> Any input on this subject or a link to a page which gives guidelines
> would be useful

There are several ways to achieve this.
When I just do a series of XSLT, I usually don't do this using a Java program,
I use the xslt/style task of Ant. Then I use the XmlValidate task to validate
both - source before the transformation and destination files after the
transformation. Of course this can be only achieved if asserting validity
against a DTD (or, if you patch the XmlValidate Task, a Schema) is
sufficient.

For more, you might want to take a look at:

* http://xmlunit.sourceforge.net/
This package provides an assertXMLEquals method that compares two strings,
taking XML equality into account, so <br></br> and <br /> are considered
equal.

* http://httpunit.sourceforge.net/
This is more powerful, but less XML-specific. It's especially then extremely
useful if you want to do HTTP based tests.

* http://xsltunit.org/
A completely different approach not based on JUnit is this Unit testing
framework proof of concept for XSLT. I really like this approach.

Depending on the task you need to solve (only assert structure or also assert
contents), a combination might be useful.
Usually for XSLT specific stuff I use validation, a perl program for
generating a file list in XML and my own XSLT stylesheet which is taking that
file list and performing unit tests against all these files.

The biggest advantage of JUnit based unit testing is the brand report
generation using JUnitReport (automation is usually achieved with Ant
anyway).

Most powerful would be a set of methods like assertXPath, though there are
some stumbling blocks:
- - One method for each XPath type or one for all of them?
- - There's no official XPath Framework for Java yet (as far as I know), only
implementations, so either use DOM and be slightly incompatible with XPath,
or use XPath and settle on a specific library like Xerces/Xalan, depending on
all changes of that library.
